kszucs commented on issue #3988: ARROW-4872: [Python] Keep backward compatibility for ParquetDatasetPiece
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3988#issuecomment-475053671
 
 
   Full error: 
   ```python
       def _parse_pandas_metadata(pandas_metadata):
           """Get the set of names from the pandas metadata section
   
           Parameters
           ----------
           pandas_metadata : dict
               Should conform to the pandas parquet metadata spec
   
           Returns
           -------
           index_names : list
               List of strings indicating the actual index names
           column_names : list
               List of strings indicating the actual column names
           storage_name_mapping : dict
               Pairs of storage names (e.g. the field names for
               PyArrow) and actual names. The storage and field names will
               differ for index names for certain writers (pyarrow > 0.8).
           column_indexes_names : list
               The names for ``df.columns.name`` or ``df.columns.names`` for
               a MultiIndex in the columns
   
           Notes
           -----
           This should support metadata written by at least
   
           * fastparquet>=0.1.3
           * pyarrow>=0.7.0
           """
           index_storage_names = pandas_metadata['index_columns']
           index_name_xpr = re.compile(r'__index_level_\d+__')
   
           # older metadatas will not have a 'field_name' field so we fall back
           # to the 'name' field
           pairs = [(x.get('field_name', x['name']), x['name'])
                    for x in pandas_metadata['columns']]
   
           # Need to reconcile storage and real names. These will differ for
           # pyarrow, which uses __index_leveL_d__ for the storage name of indexes.
           # The real name may be None (e.g. `df.index.name` is None).
           pairs2 = []
           for storage_name, real_name in pairs:
               if real_name and index_name_xpr.match(real_name):
                   real_name = None
               pairs2.append((storage_name, real_name))
           index_names = [name for (storage_name, name) in pairs2
                          if name != storage_name]
   
           # column_indexes represents df.columns.name
           # It was added to the spec after pandas 0.21.0+, and implemented
           # in PyArrow 0.8. It's not currently impelmented in fastparquet.
           column_index_names = pandas_metadata.get("column_indexes", [{'name': None}])
           column_index_names = [x['name'] for x in column_index_names]
   
           # Now we need to disambiguate between columns and index names. PyArrow
           # 0.8.0+ allows for duplicates between df.index.names and df.columns
           if not index_names:
               # For PyArrow < 0.8, Any fastparquet. This relies on the facts that
               # 1. Those versions used the real index name as the index storage name
               # 2. Those versions did not allow for duplicate index / column names
               # So we know that if a name is in index_storage_names, it must be an
               # index name
               index_names = list(index_storage_names)  # make a copy
   >           index_storage_names2 = set(index_storage_names)
   E           TypeError: unhashable type: 'dict'
   
   opt/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/dask/dataframe/io/parquet.py:91: TypeError
   ```
   
   @wesm if You have a quick hint how to resolve it please share with me :)
   The best I can think of to introduce a new key and use that instead of `column_indexes`.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

wesm commented on issue #3988: ARROW-4872: [Python] Keep backward compatibility for ParquetDatasetPiece
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3988#issuecomment-476434722
 
 
   This is very difficult to resolve. I don't think that the way that Dask interacts with either pyarrow or fastparquet is very sustainable, and I think it should be rethought. 
   
   The interactions between the index storage, the metadata (and the inconsistent implementations thereof), and the logic that infers divisions do not look good at all to me. I'm looking at this code in particular: https://github.com/dask/dask/blob/master/dask/dataframe/io/parquet.py#L795.
   
   I'm inclined to just let this be broken to force resolution within dask, which may require a fair bit of refactoring. If we keep piling hacks on top of our existing hacks, things are just going to get worse. 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

   This is very difficult to resolve. I don't think that the way that Dask interacts with either pyarrow or fastparquet is very sustainable, and I think it should be rethought. 
   
   The interactions between the index storage (and the way that the problem of index storage is left to the Parquet implementation), the metadata (and the inconsistent implementations thereof), and the logic that infers divisions do not look good at all to me. I'm looking at this code in particular: https://github.com/dask/dask/blob/master/dask/dataframe/io/parquet.py#L795.
   
   I'm inclined to just let this be broken to force resolution within dask, which may require a fair bit of refactoring. If we keep piling hacks on top of our existing hacks, things are just going to get worse.

mrocklin commented on issue #3988: ARROW-4872: [Python] Keep backward compatibility for ParquetDatasetPiece
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3988#issuecomment-476696143
 
 
   > I don't think that the way that Dask interacts with either pyarrow or fastparquet is very sustainable, and I think it should be rethought.
   
   > The interactions between the index storage (and the way that the problem of index storage is left to the Parquet implementation), the metadata (and the inconsistent implementations thereof), and the logic that infers divisions do not look good at all to me.
   
   Entirely agreed.  I started a full rewrite of Dask's parquet reader here, starting with the Arrow side of it.
   
   https://github.com/dask/dask/pull/4336
   
   However, I ran into some missing pieces in arrow, like the ability to collect metadata and write metadata files.  I would like to find some time to continue pushing on things on the Dask side here if we can quickly get a few things into Arrow.  I've tried finding resources local to me to do this, but so far haven't had luck.  I agree that generarlly it would be nice to retire the old implementations, both for future features, and for general maintenance.
   
   (sorry for my delay in response here.  was handling personal things over the last few days).
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

wesm commented on issue #3988: ARROW-4872: [Python] Keep backward compatibility for ParquetDatasetPiece
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3988#issuecomment-477123491
 
 
   The 0.13 release breaks a solid chunk of the current Dask test suite (though maybe current workflows are preserved, and existing datasets can be read fine). I spent a couple hours on it but it's a big job to fix; a lot of details of how index columns are serialized in the file have leaked into the `_get_pyarrow_divisions` function. 
   
   Given the changes we made (where RangeIndex is no longer converted to a serialized column of integers, it is stored as metadata), there is nothing that causes a fundamental issue with the way that Dask deals with pandas indexes, but all the code that is aware of the metadata and index serialization needs to be better compartmentalized and decoupled from Dask's business logic regarding divisions
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
